body: @akuznetsov-gridgain please review.

Hello, Maxim.

Thank you for the PR!

1. Should we remove idea inspection file? At lease, the one to run on TC?
2. What about other already enabled inspections? `SizeReplaceableByIsEmpty`, `RedundantSuppression`, `MissingOverrideAnnotation`?

Hello, Nikolay.

Thank you for your comment.

1. After the PR will be merged (if it will) we will get Inspection Suite and Checkstyle working both simultaneously. After we make sure that checkstyle work as expected and community adopted to new build procedure (I expect a day or two) I will create a new issue to disable the Inspection Suite and delete corresponding inspections configuration. 
Is it a plan you expect?

2. The short answer is - there is no analogue of a checkstyle module to previously configured inspections. I've mentioned everything about it in my comment in JIRA. See: [IGNITE-11277?focusedCommentId=16771200](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IGNITE-11277?focusedCommentId=16771200&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-16771200)

@nva that's because I didn't add package-lock properly ðŸ˜… With it, there's only one low severity vulnerability already addressed [here](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/pull/3270) and merged to master, but not released yet. We can update karma later.
@antonovsergey93 Your solution looks more complex. Thank you for advice. Will try it.
Please, add `package-info.java` to `org.apache.ignite.internal.processors.security`

Seems we should rename `GridSecurityProcessor` to `GridAuthenticationProcessor`. 

What do you think?
Can we mark methods that can return null and nullable fields with `@Nullable` annotation?

Updated to build against (current) master.

I'm not completely sure how to run tests... but I can run the Ignite node successfully.

One bit that might break on Linux/Windows: in a number of places it refers to `libboost-thread` but only `libboost-thread-mt` exists on my machine. I'm unclear whether this is something unique to the Mac, old versions of Boost or something else.

@alamar This behaviour is changed actually. If you have JARs lying around your repository, then they will be also loaded. 
We could introduce a new configuration property to make people enable this new feature and acknowledge the fact, that their JARs will also be loaded now. But I don't think, it's too much of a problem, so another piece of configuration seems to be an overkill to me.
Yes, as noted in the ticket, any SSL test such as TcpDiscoverySslTrustedUntrustedTest will hang on Java 11/Windows, but after this patch it would pass normally.

@yzhdanov hello!
Answers for [questions](https://github.com/apache/ignite/pull/4922#pullrequestreview-223807017):

1. The biggest issue for me was to understand logic behind classes hierarchy and 
relationships between IgniteSecurity, GridSecurityProcessor, IgniteSecurityProcessor, etc.

Answer: 
IgniteSecurity is an interface that AI is used to authorize operations. 
Developers can obtain IgniteSecurity through GridKernalContext#security method.

There are two implementations of IgniteSecurity:
- NoOpIgniteSecurityProcessor - is used when security is in disabled mode.
- IgniteSecurityProcessor - is used when security is enabled. 
IgniteSecurityProcessor gets an instance of GridSecurityProcessor while constructing and delegate it performing of authorizing operations.

Which GridSecurityProcessor should be used is defined through plugin as it was earlier.


2. do we really need "withContext()" notation?
Is that true that we never need to call withContext() several times wrapping and unwrapping the context multiple times?

Answer: That's not true, regular case is to start processing with the node's context, 
then switch to request's context or listener creator's context, and then restore the node's context.
Seems, also possible case is to call withContext() inside another withContext() when you have user1's task causes user2's task, 
but, currently we had no such feature at Ignite as far as I know.

I propose several things related to this PR:

1. Let's use a more relaxed naming. Seems that "Consistency check" sound very scary for the user. I propose to use "withReadFromAllBackups" or similar.

2. Ignite already has `CacheConfiguration#isReadFromBackup()` flag which is very similar to `consistencyCheck` flag. Do we have a feature to change `readFromBackup` in runtime?
I propose to add the ability to change both of these flags in runtime by an administrator. We shouldn't do it in the current PR, but we should create a ticket for it.

1. We should support `checkConsistency` for all cache API. 
Is there any reason to not support it?

2. We should add support of `checkConsistency` to any cache related API - queue, set, data streamers, thin client cache proxy. Can you, please, file a ticket for this changes?

3. We shouldn't restrict any `TransactionConcurrency` or `TransactionIsolation` for `withConsistency` proxy. In many cases, user code will obtain IgniteCache instance from some library code. In the time of execution specific query, there is no way to define if `IgniteCache` can execute the specific query.

Let's execute Run All with `consitencyCheck` enabled for all possible cases.
We should write a code that will enable `consitencyCheck` for all cases when it supported and run all tests in this mode.
